Paraconductivity of pseudogapped superconductors

Igor Poboiko 1,2 and Mikhail Feigelâ€™man 3,2 1 Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology, Moscow, Russia 2 National Research University â€Higher School of Economicsâ€, Moscow, Russia 3 L. D. Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics, Chernogolovka, Moscow region, Russia
Abstract

We calculate Aslamazov-Larkin paraconductity ÏƒAâ€‹Lâ€‹(T)subscriptğœğ´ğ¿ğ‘‡\sigma_{AL}(T) for a model of strongly disordered superconductors (dimensions d=2,3ğ‘‘23d=2,3) with a large pseudogap whose magnitude strongly exceeds transition temperature Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}. We show that, within Gaussian approximation over Cooper-pair fluctuations, paraconductivity is just twice larger that the classical AL result at the same Ïµ=(Tâˆ’Tc)/Tcitalic-Ïµğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\epsilon=(T-T_{c})/T_{c}. Upon decreasing Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, Gaussian approximation is violated due to local fluctuations of pairing fields that become relevant at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ1â‰ª1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1much-less-than1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}\ll 1. Characteristic scale Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1} is much larger than the width Ïµ2subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon_{2} of the thermodynamical critical region, that is determined via the Ginzburg criterion, Ïµ2â‰ˆÏµ1dsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1ğ‘‘\epsilon_{2}\approx\epsilon_{1}^{d}. We argue that in the intermediate region Ïµ2â‰¤Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ2italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{2}\leq\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1} paraconductivity follows the same AL power law, albeit with another (yet unknown) numerical prefactor. At further decrease of the temperature, all kinds of fluctuational corrections become strong at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ2italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}; in particular, conductivity occurs to be strongly inhomogeneous in real space.

I Introduction

Strongly disordered superconductors near quantum phase transition into an insulator state attract great interest during last yearsÂ t1 ; t2 ; t3 ; t4 ; e1 ; e2 ; e3 ; e4 ; NP2011 ; SacepeTiN ; Sacepe2009 ; N1 ; Teun1 . On experimental sideÂ e1 ; e2 ; e3 ; e4 ; NP2011 ; SacepeTiN ; Sacepe2009 ; N1 ; A1 ; Teun1 , new methods which became available, like low-temperature scanning tunneling spectroscopy which makes it possible to study properties of superconducting state locally with a nanometer-scale resolution. As a resultÂ NP2011 ; SacepeTiN an existence of a strong density-of-states (DoS) suppression at temperatures much above the superconducting transition Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} was demonstrated. Such a phenomenon is called pseudogap, in some rough analogy to the phenomenon known for under-doped high-Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} oxide superconductors; however, the origin of pseudogap in usual strongly disordered superconductors like InOx, see Ref.Â t1, ; t2, , is unrelated to various courses of pseudogap origin, discussed in relation to HTSC. A detailed semi-quantitative theory of superconductivity, starting from BCS-like model with localized single-electron states (near 3D Anderson localization transition) was developed in Ref.Â t1, ; t2, , elaborating an approach proposed originally in ML and developed numerically inÂ Ghosal .

One of most general phenomenon inherent to disordered superconductors is known to be fluctuational conductivity (paraconductivity) predicted long ago by Aslamazov and LarkinÂ AslamazovLarkin . It is due to appearance of fluctuational (with finite life-time) Cooper pairs at temperatures slightly above Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}. Aslamazov-Larkin (AL) paraconductivity is especially universal in 2D superconductors, where additional conductance per square is

ÏƒAâ€‹Lâ–¡=e216â€‹â„â€‹TTâˆ’Tcsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ´ğ¿â–¡superscriptğ‘’216Planck-constant-over-2-piğ‘‡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\sigma_{AL}^{\Box}=\frac{e^{2}}{16\hbar}\frac{T}{T-T_{c}}

independently of any microscopic parameters. This result is usually considered to be valid as long as ÏƒAâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğ´ğ¿\sigma_{AL} is much smaller than Drude conductance of the metal Ïƒ0subscriptğœ0\sigma_{0}, i.e. at Ïµâ‰¡T/Tcâˆ’1â‰«Gi=e2/16â€‹â„â€‹Ïƒ0italic-Ïµğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘1much-greater-thanGisuperscriptğ‘’216Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptğœ0\epsilon\equiv T/T_{c}-1\gg\mathrm{Gi}=e^{2}/16\hbar\sigma_{0}, that is, in the region of Gaussian fluctuations. In bulk systems paraconductivity is less singular, ÏƒAâ€‹Lâˆ(Tâˆ’Tc)âˆ’1/2proportional-tosubscriptğœğ´ğ¿superscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘12\sigma_{AL}\propto(T-T_{c})^{-1/2}.

More close to the transition point, within fluctuational region Ïµâ‰¤Giitalic-ÏµGi\epsilon\leq\mathrm{Gi}, interaction between superconducting fluctuations become important and results in the universal scaling behavior of thermodynamics quantitiesÂ PokrovskiiPatashinskiiBook , that is determined exclusively by space dimensionality and order parameter symmetry. In what concerns kinetic properties (like conductivity) the situation is less clear. Ref.Â LO2001, provided arguments in favor of the statement that paraconductivity is more sensitive to nonlinear effects and deviates from classical AL form already at Ïµâ‰¤Giitalic-ÏµGi\epsilon\leq\sqrt{\mathrm{Gi}}, that is, parametrically far from the scaling region. Basically, the arguments of Ref.Â LO2001, were based upon the suppression of the electron density of states (DoS) due to superconducting fluctuations: reduced DoS leads to suppression of the electron-electron inelastic rate; in turn, that leads to an increase of the order parameter relaxation time Ï„Gâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğºğ¿\tau_{GL}, with respect to its value known from the Gaussian approximation, Ï„Gâ€‹L(0)=Ï€â€‹â„/8â€‹(Tâˆ’Tc)superscriptsubscriptğœğºğ¿0ğœ‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi8ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\tau_{GL}^{(0)}=\pi\hbar/8(T-T_{c}). Since paraconductivity ÏƒAâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğ´ğ¿\sigma_{AL} can be generally shown to be proportional to the product Tâ€‹Ï„Gâ€‹Lğ‘‡subscriptğœğºğ¿T\tau_{GL}, the above consideration suggests its more singular behavior due to fluctuational suppression of the DoS. However, detailed calculations of the proposed effect were performedÂ LO2001 for the case when strong depairing is present and the whole effect is anyway weak; it remained unclear if indeed temperature behavior of paraconductivity changes qualitatively in the range Ïµâ‰¤Giitalic-ÏµGi\epsilon\leq\sqrt{\mathrm{Gi}}.

In the present paper we provide an analysis of similar problem from a different perspective. Namely, we consider very strongly disordered superconductor with a well-developed pseudogap Î”PsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{P}. An existence of pseudogap Î”PsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{P} is due to i) localized nature of single-electron eigenstates Ïˆiâ€‹(ğ’“)subscriptğœ“ğ‘–ğ’“\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), and ii) phonon-induced attraction between electrons which leads to formation of localized electron pairs (with opposite spins) populating eigenstates Ïˆiâ€‹(ğ’“)subscriptğœ“ğ‘–ğ’“\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{r}). The energy gain due to formation of such a pair is Î”PsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{P}. Next, hybridization matrix elements Jiâ€‹jsubscriptğ½ğ‘–ğ‘—J_{ij} provide virtual hopping of electron pairs between different localized eigenstates. If this hopping is sufficiently strong, a superconducting coherent state is formed below some critical temperature Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}; â€‰ (for detailed theory of pseudogaped superconductivity seeÂ t2 ).

Below we consider the case of Î”PsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{P} that is much larger than Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}, like it was found in InOx thick films studied in Ref.NP2011, . In such a case one may neglect, to a first approximation over Tc/Î”Pâ‰ª1much-less-thansubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ1T_{c}/\Delta_{P}\ll 1, the presence of single-electron states: the single-particle DoS will be set to zero. We will show, nevertheless, that the whole qualitative picture of critical fluctuations, including their dynamics, remains the same as for usual disordered superconductors, as long as we stick to the Gaussian fluctuation region. The major difference we found is that now Ï„Gâ€‹L(0)=Ï€â€‹â„/4â€‹(Tâˆ’Tc)superscriptsubscriptğœğºğ¿0ğœ‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi4ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\tau_{GL}^{(0)}=\pi\hbar/4(T-T_{c}), i.e. twice larger than the result of the standard theory.

This result is valid as long as thermal fluctuations are weak and their interaction can be neglected. For such a region to exist at Ïµâ‰¤1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon\leq 1 in a pseudogapped superconductor, a special assumption is necessary; namely, we consider the model with interaction matrix elements Jiâ€‹jsubscriptğ½ğ‘–ğ‘—J_{ij} possessing large coordination number Zâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘1Z\gg 1 for the relevant eigenstates which have eigenenergies Îµi,Îµjsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘—\varepsilon_{i},\varepsilon_{j} located within about Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} from Fermi energy. The presence of large parameter Zğ‘Z allows us to derive a dynamical Ginzburg-Landau functional for superconducting fluctuations at Tğ‘‡T near Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} and to calculate paraconductivity at Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ1â‰ª1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1much-less-than1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}\ll 1 where explicit value of Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1} depends both on Zğ‘Z and on space dimensionality dğ‘‘d (we consider d=2,3ğ‘‘23d=2,3 ). At smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon interaction between fluctuations becomes strong enough to affect kinetic coefficient of the Ginzburg-Landau functional, thus the kinetic problem cannot be solved analytically; however, we provide some arguments in favor of the same type power-law singularity in paraconductivity ÏƒAâ€‹Lâˆ(Tâˆ’Tc)(dâˆ’4)/2proportional-tosubscriptğœğ´ğ¿superscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‘42\sigma_{AL}\propto(T-T_{c})^{(d-4)/2} to exist down to much smaller values of Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ2italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{2}. Here Ïµ2subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon_{2} provides a boundary of the region where all thermodynamic fluctuational effects become strong, it is analogous to the Ginzburg parameter in the usual theory of second-order phase transitions; the important point is that Ïµ2â‰ªÏµ1much-less-thansubscriptitalic-Ïµ2subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{2}\ll\epsilon_{1} as long as Ïµ1â‰ª1much-less-thansubscriptitalic-Ïµ11\epsilon_{1}\ll 1.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in Sec.II we formulate our model based upon Anderson pseudospinÂ  AndersonPseudo representation of the even-only sector of BCS Hamiltonian for localized single-electron states; we provide initial mean-field-like analysis in II.1 and then in Sec.II.2 we develop Popov-Fedotov semionic diagrammatic technique that is convenient to treat long-range and long-time properties of the model near the critical point. Sec. III is devoted to the derivation of the dynamic Ginzburg-Landau functional and to the calculation of the paraconductivity within Gaussian approximation for 2D and 3D systems. In Sec. IV we analyze leading non-Gaussian corrections and estimate characteristic temperature scale Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1}; we find that it scales as Zâˆ’1/2superscriptğ‘12Z^{-1/2} and Zâˆ’2/3superscriptğ‘23Z^{-2/3} in 2D and 3D cases, correspondingly; we also analyze the effect of these non-Gaussian corrections upon dependence of ÏƒAâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğ´ğ¿\sigma_{AL} on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Then, in Sec.V we consider all other effects beyond the leading Gaussian approximation; these effects are: a) the lack of self-averaging due to strong spatial fluctuations of disorder, and b) infra-red dominated thermal fluctuations of collective modes. We show that corresponding reduced temperature scale Ïµ2âˆ1/Zproportional-tosubscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğ‘\epsilon_{2}\propto 1/Z in 2D model, and âˆ1/Z2proportional-toabsent1superscriptğ‘2\propto 1/Z^{2} in 3D; note that it is the same scaling as it is known for the Ginzburg number GiGi\mathrm{Gi} in usual phase transition theory. Sec. VI contains our conclusions. Some technical details are presented in Appendices A, B, C and D.

II The model and diagram technique

The starting point of our approach is representation of the paired electron system in terms of pseudospin operators introduced long ago by P.W.AndersonÂ AndersonPseudo :

II.2 Semionic description and Keldysh diagram technique

In order to study the dynamical properties of the order parameter and develop a diagram technique, we choose the Fedotov-Popov representation for spin-1212\frac{1}{2} operatorsFedotovPopov ; Shtyk . Namely, for each spin we introduce a two-component spinor Ïˆ=(Ïˆâ†‘,Ïˆâ†“)ğœ“subscriptğœ“â†‘subscriptğœ“â†“\psi=(\psi_{\uparrow},\psi_{\downarrow}) describing a pair of fermions (called semions for the reason that will become clear soon), and represent spin operators in terms of semions (below Ïƒ^Î±superscript^ğœğ›¼\hat{\sigma}^{\alpha} is the set of Pauli matrices acting in the (â†‘,â†“)â†‘â†“({\uparrow},{\downarrow}) space):

II.3 Electric current

Anderson pseudospin operators SiÂ±subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†plus-or-minusğ‘–S^{\pm}_{i} create and annihilate pair of electrons on site iğ‘–i. The electromagnetic gauge transformation thus acts as Uâ€‹(1)ğ‘ˆ1U(1) rotation on the spin operators SiÂ±â†¦SiÂ±â€‹eÂ±2â€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹Î±â€‹(ğ’“i)maps-tosubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†plus-or-minusğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†plus-or-minusğ‘–superscriptğ‘’plus-or-minus2ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ›¼subscriptğ’“ğ‘–S^{\pm}_{i}\mapsto S^{\pm}_{i}e^{\pm 2ie\alpha(\boldsymbol{r}_{i})} (with eğ‘’e being electron charge, while speed of light is taken c=1ğ‘1c=1). Accompanied by the gauge transformation for the vector potential ğ‘¨â€‹(ğ’“)â†¦ğ‘¨â€‹(ğ’“)âˆ’âˆ‡Î±maps-toğ‘¨ğ’“ğ‘¨ğ’“âˆ‡ğ›¼\boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{r})\mapsto\boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{r})-\nabla\alpha this should leave the action (11) unchanged.

Real space enters problem via the J^=Jâ€‹(p^=âˆ’iâ€‹âˆ‡)^ğ½ğ½^ğ‘ğ‘–âˆ‡\hat{J}=J(\hat{p}=-i\nabla) matrix. The electrical current induced by Cooper pairs can be extracted from the action using the following relation:

ğ’‹=Î´â€‹SÎ´â€‹ğ‘¨=4â€‹eâ€‹R2Jâ€‹Î¦Î±â€‹[Ïƒ^Î±â€‹Î²yâ€‹ğ’‘^âˆ’2â€‹eâ€‹ğ‘¨â€‹Î´Î±â€‹Î²]â€‹Î¦Î².ğ’‹ğ›¿ğ‘†ğ›¿ğ‘¨4ğ‘’superscriptğ‘…2ğ½superscriptÎ¦ğ›¼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœğ‘¦ğ›¼ğ›½^ğ’‘2ğ‘’ğ‘¨subscriptğ›¿ğ›¼ğ›½superscriptÎ¦ğ›½\boldsymbol{j}=\frac{\delta S}{\delta\boldsymbol{A}}=\frac{4eR^{2}}{J}\Phi^{\alpha}\left[\hat{\sigma}^{y}_{\alpha\beta}\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}-2e\boldsymbol{A}\delta_{\alpha\beta}\right]\Phi^{\beta}. (16)

This relation holds on the classical field theory level, and it is translated to an operator identity of the corresponding quantum theory.

The presence of a linear in Ï‰ğœ”\omega term is thus a direct consequence of the non-zero single-spin density of states Î½0=Pâ€‹(Îµâ‰ªT)subscriptğœˆ0ğ‘ƒmuch-less-thanğœ€ğ‘‡\nu_{0}=P(\varepsilon\ll T).

The above calculation leads to the following form of the order parameter propagator:

We should emphasize that the form of the propagator (26) is independent of the exact shape of the distribution function provided it has non-zero DoS Î½0=Pâ€‹(Îµ=0)subscriptğœˆ0ğ‘ƒğœ€0\nu_{0}=P(\varepsilon=0) and does not change significantly at Îµâ‰²Ï‰less-than-or-similar-toğœ€ğœ”\varepsilon\lesssim\omega. This form of the propagator is reminiscent of the ordinary time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau (TDGL)VarlamovLarkin theory describing the dynamics of the order parameter in the metals close to the superconducting transition. The difference is that in our theory Î¾0subscriptğœ‰0\xi_{0} does not scale with Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} as it does in disordered metals, where Î¾0âˆ¼D/Tcsimilar-tosubscriptğœ‰0ğ·subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\xi_{0}\sim\sqrt{D/T_{c}}; another important difference is that the parameter Ï„ğœ\tau we found if twice larger compared to the value known for disordered metals, where Ï„=Ï€/8â€‹Tğœğœ‹8ğ‘‡\tau=\pi/8T.

III.2 Fluctuational conductivity

We found in the previous Section that dynamics of our order parameter appears to be similar to the usual TDGL. Paraconductivity in superconductors above Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} was calculated long time ago by Aslamazov and Larkin AslamazovLarkin , while its calculation using TDGL formalism can be found in Ref. VarlamovLarkin . In this Section we briefly recapitulate the calculation and discuss the obtained results.

In order to obtain the expression for the electric conductivity of the system, one can apply Kubo formula,

where current-current correlation function in real space-time reads

and Eq.(28) contains its Fourier transform to (ğ’’,Ï‰)ğ’’ğœ”(\boldsymbol{q},\omega) representation.

This result appears to be twice larger compared to the ordinary Aslamazov-Larkin resultAslamazovLarkin . The discrepancy can be traced back to the fact that Ï„ğœ\tau is twice larger compared to the ordinary metals, which we have briefly mentioned above. While in ordinary superconductors the AL paraconductivity provides a relatively small correction to the standard Drude conductivity ÏƒDsubscriptğœğ·\sigma_{D}, in our system with a large pseudogap, paraconductivity ÏƒAâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğ´ğ¿\sigma_{AL} may occur to be the dominant contribution: the only alternative conduction channel is due to individual electrons hopping between localized states, those contribution is suppressed additionally due to Tcâ‰ªÎ”Pmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒT_{c}\ll\Delta_{P} condition.

Below we will study different kinds of corrections to the Gaussian approximation we used, and show that Eq.(33) provides a very good approximation if Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}, see Eqs. (38,39) below. Then we analyze corrections that appear at smaller values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

IV Local noise effect

Non-Gaussian effects due to interaction between fluctuating collective modes are generally known to become important for thermodynamics quantities in the close proximity of the critical point at Ïµâ‰¤Giitalic-ÏµGi\epsilon\leq\mathrm{Gi}, where Ginzburg number Giâˆ¼Zâˆ’2/(4âˆ’d)similar-toGisuperscriptğ‘24ğ‘‘\mathrm{Gi}\sim Z^{-2/(4-d)}. However, it was noticed in Ref.Â LO2001 , that for dynamics quantities (in particular, for paraconductivity) interaction corrections may become large in a parametrically broader range of reduced temperature Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. In the present Section we show that similar phenomenon comes about in our model as well. Namely, we find a rather special type of interaction corrections that affects the dependence of the relaxation time Ï„Gâ€‹Lsubscriptğœğºğ¿\tau_{GL} on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, which become relevant already at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ1âˆ¼Gi1/ditalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1similar-tosuperscriptGi1ğ‘‘\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}\sim\mathrm{Gi}^{1/d}, whereas all static quantities are still well-described within Gaussian approximation.

Specific kind of interaction corrections relevant at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1} can be understood as a result of local â€back-actionâ€ of the order parameter (superconducting) fluctuations upon dynamics of individual â€pseudospinsâ€ Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}. Indeed, Keldysh action (11) describes its dynamics under the fluctuating local â€œmagnetic fieldâ€ (Î¦ixâ€‹(t),Î¦iyâ€‹(t),Îµi)subscriptsuperscriptÎ¦ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptÎ¦ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœ€ğ‘–(\Phi^{x}_{i}(t),\Phi^{y}_{i}(t),\varepsilon_{i}). Since local correlation functions of the field ğš½iâ€‹(t)subscriptğš½ğ‘–ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}(t) coincide with the propagator Lâ€‹(Ï‰,ğ’“,ğ’“â€²)ğ¿ğœ”ğ’“superscriptğ’“â€²L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}) calculated at ğ’“=ğ’“â€²=ğ’“iğ’“superscriptğ’“â€²subscriptğ’“ğ‘–\boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{r}_{i}, the action (11) together with Dyson equation (17) constitute a closed set of self-consistent equations. Solution of these equations would involve: i) finding dynamical correlation functions of a spin SisubscriptSğ‘–\mathrm{S}_{i} under the action of dynamic â€™magnetic fieldâ€™ with a given correlation function of the local â€noise functionâ€ Ciâ€‹(tâˆ’tâ€²)=âŸ¨Î¦iÎ±â€‹(t)â€‹Î¦iÎ²â€‹(tâ€²)âŸ©subscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptsuperscriptÎ¦ğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptÎ¦ğ›½ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¡â€²C_{i}(t-t^{\prime})=\langle\Phi^{\alpha}_{i}(t)\Phi^{\beta}_{i}(t^{\prime})\rangle ; ii) calculation of the propagator Lâ€‹(Ï‰,ğ’“,ğ’“â€²)ğ¿ğœ”ğ’“superscriptğ’“â€²L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r},\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}) via Dyson equation; iii) self-consistent determination of the local noise function for each site iğ‘–i. In general, the above scheme contains a macroscopic number of variables and thus it is untackleable. The problem can be grossly simplified if site-iğ‘–i dependent noise function can be approximated by a single universal function: Ciâ€‹(tâˆ’tâ€²)â†’Câ€‹(tâˆ’tâ€²)â†’subscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ¶ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²C_{i}(t-t^{\prime})\to C(t-t^{\prime}). Below in Sec.V we will see that such an approximation is indeed valid in the range Giâ‰ªÏµâ‰¤Ïµ1much-less-thanGiitalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathrm{Gi}\ll\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}. Currently we take it for granted and study the effect of such a transverse noise upon local spin-spin dynamics, order parameter dynamics and, eventually, upon paraconductivity.

The key characteristic of the noise is provided by the propagator at the coinciding points Lâ€‹(Ï‰,ğ’“=ğ’“â€²)ğ¿ğœ”ğ’“superscriptğ’“â€²L(\omega,\boldsymbol{r}=\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}). This quantity itself is ultraviolet divergent (with momentum integration should be cut off at Î›âˆ¼Râˆ’1similar-toÎ›superscriptğ‘…1\Lambda\sim R^{-1}), but relevant Ï‰ğœ”\omega and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-dependent part can be separated and is determined by the infrared behavior:

LRâ€‹(Ï‰)â‰ˆ18â€‹Ï€â€‹Î½0â€‹Î¾0dâ€‹{lnâ¡(Î›2â€‹Î¾02)âˆ’lnâ¡(Ïµâˆ’iâ€‹Ï‰â€‹Ï„),(2â€‹D)Î›â€‹Î¾0âˆ’Ïµâˆ’iâ€‹Ï‰â€‹Ï„,(3â€‹D).subscriptğ¿ğ‘…ğœ”18ğœ‹subscriptğœˆ0superscriptsubscriptğœ‰0ğ‘‘casessuperscriptÎ›2superscriptsubscriptğœ‰02italic-Ïµğ‘–ğœ”ğœ2ğ·Î›subscriptğœ‰0italic-Ïµğ‘–ğœ”ğœ3ğ·L_{R}(\omega)\approx\frac{1}{8\pi\nu_{0}\xi_{0}^{d}}\begin{cases}\ln(\Lambda^{2}\xi_{0}^{2})-\ln(\epsilon-i\omega\tau),&(2D)\\ \Lambda\xi_{0}-\sqrt{\epsilon-i\omega\tau},&(3D)\end{cases}. (34)

The â€œlocal noiseâ€ described by this propagator is small provided Î¾0subscriptğœ‰0\xi_{0} is large enough.

IV.1 Spin relaxation and renormalization

The effect of the â€œnoiseâ€ caused by the order parameter fluctuations on the spin correlation function can be studied perturbatively using the Keldysh action (11). There are, in general, two types of such a corrections: to a semionic propagator and to a vertex part, and we start from the first one.

The simplest diagram for the semionic propagator correction is shown on Fig. 4. Below we will focus only on the â€œâ†“â†“\downarrowâ€ semionic branch, as the expressions for â€œâ†‘â†‘\uparrowâ€ can be obtained simply by replacing Îµâ†’âˆ’Îµâ†’ğœ€ğœ€\varepsilon\to-\varepsilon. Î£Râ†“â€‹(Ï‰,Îµ)=âˆ’i2â€‹âˆ«dâ€‹Î©2â€‹Ï€â€‹(GRâ†‘â€‹(Î©)â€‹LKâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ’Î©)+GKâ†‘â€‹(Ï‰âˆ’Î©)â€‹LRâ€‹(Î©))superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘…â†“ğœ”ğœ€ğ‘–2ğ‘‘Î©2ğœ‹superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘…â†‘Î©subscriptğ¿ğ¾ğœ”Î©superscriptsubscriptğºğ¾â†‘ğœ”Î©subscriptğ¿ğ‘…Î©\Sigma_{R}^{\downarrow}(\omega,\varepsilon)=-\frac{i}{2}\int\frac{d\Omega}{2\pi}(G_{R}^{\uparrow}(\Omega)L_{K}(\omega-\Omega)+G_{K}^{\uparrow}(\omega-\Omega)L_{R}(\Omega)) (35)

Although semions do not correspond to real quasiparticles in the system, their properties nevertheless describe the physical spin correlation function. Namely, Imâ¡Î£RImsubscriptÎ£ğ‘…\operatorname{Im}\Sigma_{R} corresponds to the real processes of spin relaxation, and Reâ¡Î£RResubscriptÎ£ğ‘…\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} describes renormalization of the spectrum. In the lowest order of perturbation theory, these two effects can be studied separately, and we start with the spin relaxation processes.

IV.2 Correction to the order parameter propagator

The semionic renormalization discussed above affects the spin correlation function, which enters the Dyson equation for the order parameter. The prime effect is upon the dissipative part of the order parameter propagator Lâ€‹(Ï‰,ğ’’)ğ¿ğœ”ğ’’L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), which is determined by the spectral weight of the spin correlation function, see Eq.(44). The major contribution to the above average over local energies Îµğœ€\varepsilon comes from Îµâˆ¼Ï‰â‰ªTsimilar-toğœ€ğœ”much-less-thanğ‘‡\varepsilon\sim\omega\ll T, thus the factor linear in Ï‰ğœ”\omega comes just from the expansion of the Fermi distribution function, ğ”£â€‹(Ï‰)â‰ˆÎ²â€‹Ï‰ğ”£ğœ”ğ›½ğœ”\mathfrak{f}(\omega)\approx\beta\omega. This allows us to write the following formula for the important dimensionless parameter Tâ€‹Ï„ğ‘‡ğœT\tau, which now can depend on frequency Ï‰ğœ”\omega (we remind that paraconductivity is proportional to it, and on the Gaussian level this parameter was Ï€/4ğœ‹4\pi/4):

In the previous section we have shown that real part of semionic self-energy Reâ¡Î£RResubscriptÎ£ğ‘…\operatorname{Re}\Sigma_{R} does not affect the product Tâ€‹Ï„ğ‘‡ğœT\tau, while Imâ¡Î£RImsubscriptÎ£ğ‘…\operatorname{Im}\Sigma_{R} can be accounted for by the substitution of the propagators in the form (13) with nonzero Î³ğ›¾\gamma, given by (37):

IV.3 Effect on the paraconductivity

Let us now study the implication of the non-Gaussian effect discussed above upon the paraconductivity. We need to consider the corrections to the Qğ‘„Q-kernel given by Fig. 3. In the leading order one should consider the same diagram, but with dressed order parameter Green functions, which we have studied in the previous Section.

As it can be seen from the calculation in Sec. III.2, the main contribution to the paraconductivity comes from the order parameter fluctuations with energies Ï‰â€‹Ï„âˆ¼Ïµsimilar-toğœ”ğœitalic-Ïµ\omega\tau\sim\epsilon and momenta pâ€‹Î¾0âˆ¼Ïµsimilar-toğ‘subscriptğœ‰0italic-Ïµp\xi_{0}\sim\sqrt{\epsilon}. In the previous Section we have shown that the back-effect coming from the dynamics of â€noisy spinsâ€ changes the constant Tâ€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‡ğœğœ”T\tau(\omega) at frequencies Ï‰â‰²Ï‰cless-than-or-similar-toğœ”subscriptğœ”ğ‘\omega\lesssim\omega_{c} only. Thus we conclude, that this renormalization is negligible provided Ï‰câ‰ªÏµâ€‹T=|Tâˆ’Tc|much-less-thansubscriptğœ”ğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘‡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\omega_{c}\ll\epsilon T=|T-T_{c}|, which, in turn, leads to the applicability criterion for Eq. (33) in a form Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1} with Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1} given by Eqs.(38,39).

At smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the contribution of spins those dynamics is strongly affected by the noise, becomes dominant. However, as we saw in the previous Subsection, this effect can hardly change the kinetic coefficient Ï„ğœ\tau more substantially than by some factor of order unity; therefore we expect Aslamazov-Larkin-type paraconductivity, Eq.(33), to be valid qualitatively even at smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, down to Ïµâ‰¥Ïitalic-ÏµğœŒ\epsilon\geq\rho. Another types of corrections that come into play at still lower Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, will be considered in the next Section.

V Other types of fluctuational corrections

In the previous Section a special kind of a fluctuational correction was demonstrated, that becomes relevant for kinetic properties of our system in a relatively broad of reduced temperatures Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{1}, where Ïµ1âˆ¼Ï1/2similar-tosubscriptitalic-Ïµ1superscriptğœŒ12\epsilon_{1}\sim\rho^{1/2} in 2D, and Ïµ1âˆ¼Ï2/3similar-tosubscriptitalic-Ïµ1superscriptğœŒ23\epsilon_{1}\sim\rho^{2/3} in 3D. On the other hand, standard Ginzburg criterion for the width of fluctuation-dominated region near second-order phase transition reads as Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ2â‰¡Giâˆ¼Zâˆ’24âˆ’ditalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2Gisimilar-tosuperscriptğ‘24ğ‘‘\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}\equiv\mathrm{Gi}\sim Z^{-\frac{2}{4-d}}, where Zâˆ¼1/Ïsimilar-toğ‘1ğœŒZ\sim 1/\rho is an effective number of â€interacting neighboursâ€, see Eqs.(38,39). Thus we conclude that Ïµ2âˆ¼Ïµ1dâ‰ªÏµ1similar-tosubscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1ğ‘‘much-less-thansubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{2}\sim\epsilon_{1}^{d}\ll\epsilon_{1} for d=2,3ğ‘‘23d=2,3.

Below in this Section we will consider some additional corrections to the Gaussian approximation of Sec.III, which are specific to the presence of strong disorder in our model; we will show that these effects also become relevant at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ2italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2} only. Namely, we concentrate on the corrections to the approximation Î Ë‡=âŸ¨SË‡âŸ©ÎµË‡Î subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©Ë‡ğ‘†ğœ€\check{\Pi}=\left\langle\check{S}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon} for the self-energy of the order parameter propagator Lâ€‹(Ï‰,ğ’’)ğ¿ğœ”ğ’’L(\omega,\boldsymbol{q}), as defined by the Dyson equation (19).

In the calculation shown in the section III.1 we have studied the order parameter propagator averaged over the disorder by means of the Dyson equation (19), where in the leading approximation we used the self-energy Î Ë‡=âŸ¨SË‡âŸ©ÎµË‡Î subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©Ë‡ğ‘†ğœ€\check{\Pi}=\left\langle\check{S}\right\rangle_{\varepsilon}. The same approximation was employed in the calculation of all other quantities we have studied â€” including paraconductivity itself. In this Section we will study the deviations from the results of this approximation, using the semion diagram technique.

VI Conclusions

We have shown in this paper that fluctuational conductivity effect, originally predicted by L.Aslamazov and A.Larkin 50 years ago, remains nearly the same in the case of strongly pseudo-gaped superconductors with just absent single-electron density of states. The role of single-electron states is taken over by the localized electron pairs, and the effect of that replacement reduces just to the factor of 2 change of the numerical coefficient Ïƒdsubscriptğœğ‘‘\sigma_{d} in Eqs. (32,33) w.r.t. to the classical Aslamazov-Larkin result, while power-law dependence of paraconductivity on Ïµ=lnâ¡(T/Tc)italic-Ïµğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\epsilon=\ln(T/T_{c}) remains the same. Our results were derived under the assumption that hopping of (initially) localized pairs occurs with a large effective â€coordination numberâ€ Zâˆ¼Ïâˆ’1similar-toğ‘superscriptğœŒ1Z\sim\rho^{-1}, see Eq.(38,39).

Universal character of the AL paraconductivity (especially, in 2D) makes it convenient experimental tool for determination of the critical temperature when Râ€‹(T)ğ‘…ğ‘‡R(T) dependence is of considerable width, like it occurs in strongly disordered superconductors. For this reason, the issue of universality of the value of numerical coefficient Ïƒdsubscriptğœğ‘‘\sigma_{d} is of interest. First, we note that it does not depend upon the shape of the local energy distribution function Pâ€‹(Îµ)ğ‘ƒğœ€P(\varepsilon) as long as it is flat on the scale of very small Îµâˆ¼Tcsimilar-toğœ€subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\varepsilon\sim T_{c}. Some nontrivial structure at this energy scale in the effective distribution Pâ€‹(Îµ)ğ‘ƒğœ€P(\varepsilon) may come about in the generalized model where long-range interaction of the type of Sizâ€‹Uâ€‹(ğ’“iâˆ’ğ’“j)â€‹Sjzsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ’“ğ‘–subscriptğ’“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘§S_{i}^{z}U(\boldsymbol{r}_{i}-\boldsymbol{r}_{j})S_{j}^{z} is included, that can be traced back to the Coulomb interaction between charges of localized pairs. The effect of such an interaction will be studied separately.

Since our condition of a very large pseudogap Î”Pâ‰«Tcmuch-greater-thansubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\Delta_{P}\gg T_{c} may be found too restrictive in applications, one might be interested in generalization of our result for moderate value of Î”Pâˆ¼Tcsimilar-tosubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\Delta_{P}\sim T_{c}. That can be done in a rather straightforward way, once we note that the whole issue of the coefficient Ïƒdsubscriptğœğ‘‘\sigma_{d} in Eq.(33) is controlled by the expansion of the effective spin distribution function ğ”£â€‹(Ï‰)=tanhâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰ğ”£ğœ”ğ›½ğœ”\mathfrak{f}(\omega)=\tanh\beta\omega over small Ï‰ğœ”\omega. In the standard TDGL theory VarlamovLarkin for disordered superconductors, the fermionic distribution function fâ€‹(Ï‰)=tanhâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰2ğ‘“ğœ”ğ›½ğœ”2f(\omega)=\tanh\frac{\beta\omega}{2} stays instead of ğ”£â€‹(Ï‰)ğ”£ğœ”\mathfrak{f}(\omega), thus making the coefficient in front of Tâ€‹Ï„ğ‘‡ğœT\tau twice smaller than in our problem, see Eq.(27). For the general case of Î”Pâˆ¼Tcsimilar-tosubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\Delta_{P}\sim T_{c} we can use an observation presented in the Appendix B to the paperÂ t2 : for an arbitrary Î”P/TsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\Delta_{P}/T, a generalized distribution function is

ğ”£â€‹(Ï‰,Î”P)=sinhâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰coshâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰+eâˆ’Î”P/Tğ”£ğœ”subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒğ›½ğœ”ğ›½ğœ”superscriptğ‘’subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\mathfrak{f}(\omega,\Delta_{P})=\frac{\sinh\beta\omega}{\cosh\beta\omega+e^{-\Delta_{P}/T}}

which interpolate between tanhâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰2ğ›½ğœ”2\tanh\frac{\beta\omega}{2} and tanhâ¡Î²â€‹Ï‰ğ›½ğœ”\tanh\beta\omega upon increase of Î”P/TsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\Delta_{P}/T. As a result, for a generic Î”PsubscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{P} values, the enhancement factor in Ïƒdsubscriptğœğ‘‘\sigma_{d}, w.r.t. to the standard AL result, is given by 2/(1+eâˆ’Î”P/Tc)21superscriptğ‘’subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘2/(1+e^{-\Delta_{P}/T_{c}}), i.e. it quickly becomes close to 2 for moderate Î”P/Tâ‰¥1.5subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒğ‘‡1.5\Delta_{P}/T\geq 1.5.

All the above discussion refers to the Gaussian fluctuation region, Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1}, see Eqs.(38),(39). At smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon non-linear corrections to the dynamics of the order parameter becomes important, they are discussed in Sec. IV. However, we present the arguments that power-law character of ÏƒAâ€‹Lâ€‹(Ïµ)subscriptğœğ´ğ¿italic-Ïµ\sigma_{AL}(\epsilon) dependence is not changed due to these â€local noiseâ€ effects, while the coefficient Ïƒdsubscriptğœğ‘‘\sigma_{d} becomes somewhat different. Even more close to Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}, at Ïµâ‰¤Ïµ2=Giitalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ2Gi\epsilon\leq\epsilon_{2}=\mathrm{Gi}, all types of fluctuational corrections becomes relevant, which makes calculation of ÏƒAâ€‹Lâ€‹(Ïµ)subscriptğœğ´ğ¿italic-Ïµ\sigma_{AL}(\epsilon) difficult. Moreover, in this close proximity of Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}, conductivity becomes spatially inhomogenuous, as evidenced by Eq.(56).

Specific feature of fluctuational conductivity in superconductors close to SIT is that it may much exceed bare (unrelated to superconducting correlations) conductivity already in the region of Ïµâ‰¥Ïµ1italic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon\geq\epsilon_{1} where Gaussian approximation is valid. This is due to the absence in our case of the standard Drude contribution of the normal-metal type. Instead, Aslamazov-Larkin paraconductivity competes with hopping conductivity of individual electrons, that is further suppressed at Tâ‰ªÎ”Pmuch-less-thanğ‘‡subscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒT\ll\Delta_{P}.

The shift of the spectrum edge leads to the renormalization of the coupling constant Jeff=Jâ€‹(1+Î»G)subscriptğ½effğ½1subscriptğœ†ğºJ_{\textrm{eff}}=J(1+\lambda_{G}) in expression for Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c}, Eq.(7), thus increasing the critical temperature slightly.

To support this calculation, we have performed numerical analysis of the spectrum of corresponding random matrix. The temperature T=Î²âˆ’1ğ‘‡superscriptğ›½1T=\beta^{-1} was taken close to the mean-field value of the critical temperature (7), so that spectrum edge is estimated to be close to unity. The Jiâ€‹jsubscriptğ½ğ‘–ğ‘—J_{ij} matrix was taken Gaussian, so that its Fourier transform has the form Jâ€‹(ğ’’)=Jâ€‹expâ¡(âˆ’q2â€‹R2)ğ½ğ’’ğ½superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘…2J(\boldsymbol{q})=J\exp(-q^{2}R^{2}); in that case the integration in Eq. (65) can be performed explicitly leaving the single algebraic equation for Î¨Î¨\Psi, which is then solved numerically to obtain the analytic fitting curve. The amount of disorder realization varied from âˆ¼similar-to\sim30000 (for smallest system) to âˆ¼similar-to\sim6000 for largest one.

The typical DoS pictures shown on Fig. 9 consists of the â€œmain bodyâ€ of the DoS, which is fitted by the SCBA formula reasonably well, and the exponential tail of localized states which always arise when one deals with random matrices. The oscillatory behavior is due to finite-size effects and momentum quantization in a system of finite size; they tend to increase upon increasing Rğ‘…R and decreasing Lğ¿L. The superconductivity appears when the mobility edge separating localized and delocalized states crosses unity eigenvalue. Clearly, the edge of the spectrum is larger than unity, and the SCBA result, Eq. (68) gives the better estimation of the position of the edge as well as the whole curve.

The width of the tail Î“Î“\Gamma is known to be related to the Ginzburg number Giâˆ¼Ï2/(4âˆ’d)âˆRâˆ’2â€‹d/(4âˆ’d)similar-toGisuperscriptğœŒ24ğ‘‘proportional-tosuperscriptğ‘…2ğ‘‘4ğ‘‘\mathrm{Gi}\sim\rho^{2/(4-d)}\propto R^{-2d/(4-d)}. To support this claim, we performed numerical simulations for system with various Rğ‘…R and estimated the Rğ‘…R-dependency of the width of the tail. The beginning of the tail was determined by the intersection of the tangent line to the curve in the inflection point with the xğ‘¥x-axis, see Fig. 9. The best fit of the Î“â€‹(R)Î“ğ‘…\Gamma(R) dependency is shown on Fig. 10, and corresponds to Î“â€‹(R)âˆ¼Râˆ’2similar-toÎ“ğ‘…superscriptğ‘…2\Gamma(R)\sim R^{-2}, which agrees with the prediction for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2.
